div.l: This Miller to the towne his doughter sende
For ale ⁊and breed ⁊and rostede hem a goos
And bonde here hors it shulde namore go loos
And in his owne chambre he made a bedde
With schetis ⁊and with chalons fair͗e spredde
Nought from his owne bedde ten foot or twelue
His doughter had a bed all bi here selue
Right in the same chambre by ⁊and by
It myght be no bette ⁊and cause whi
Ther was no romer herberwe in the place
Thei soupen ⁊and thei speken hem to solace
And drynken eủere strong ale atte beste
A boute mydnyght wente thei to reste
Well hath þis Miller vernysched his heed
Full pale he was for dronken ⁊and nought reed
He yexeth ⁊and speketh thorough the nose
As he ware on the quakke or on the pose
To bedde he goth ⁊and with hym goth his wif
As any Iaie he light was ⁊and iolif
So was here ioly whistell well wette
The cradell at here beddis feet is sette
To rocken ⁊and to yeue the childe to souke
And whan that dronken was all in the crouke
To bedde wente the doughter right a noon
To bedde goth Aleyn ⁊and also Iohn
Ther nas no more · them nedede no dwale
This Miller hath so wisly bibbed ale
That as an hors he snorteth in his slepe
Ne of his taile be hynde he toke no kepe
His wif bare hym a burdon a full strong
Men myghten her routyng heren a forlong
The wenche routeth ek ꝑpar companye
Aleyn the clerk that herde this melodye
He pouked Iohn ⁊and seide slepist thou
Herdist thou eủer slik a sang or now
Lo swilke a couplyng is be twixe hem alle
A wilde fyre on thair bodies falle
Ho herkned euyr swilk a ferly thyng
Ye thei sall haue the flour of ill endyng
This lang nyght ther tides me na reste
But yet na force all schall be for the beste
For Iohn seide he as eủer mote I thryue
Yf that I may yon wenche will I swyue
Som esement hath lawe schapen vs
For Iohn ther is a lawe that saieth thus
That if a man in oo poynt be a greued
That in an other he schall be releued
